    Introducing narrator

Introducing narrator

Source: vignettes/intro.Rmd
intro.Rmd
library(narrator)
library(dplyr)
library(knitr)

Descriptive Narrative

Basic narrative type is descriptive stats, looking into outliers or biggest contributors to the total volumes in the data set. This narratives are quite useful and can help to look deeper into the data set hierarchy.

Simple Table

Starting with a simplest table that has only one dimension and one measure. Here overall sales volume as well as outlying Territories will be analyzed.

df_one <- sales %>%
  group_by(Territory) %>%
  summarise(Sales = sum(Sales, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(Sales))

kable(df_one)
Territory Sales
EMEA 4979272.4
NA 3852061.4
APAC 746121.8
Japan 455173.2 
narrate_descriptive(df_one)

Sales across all Territories is 10 M. Outlying Territories by Sales are EMEA (5 M, 49.6 %), NA (3.9 M, 38.4 %).

Multiple Dimensions 

df_two <- sales %>%
  filter(Territory %in% c("NA", "EMEA")) %>%
  group_by(Territory, Productline) %>%
  summarise(Sales = sum(Sales, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(Sales))

kable(df_two)
Territory Productline Sales
EMEA Classic Cars 2086994.66
NA Classic Cars 1406261.44
EMEA Vintage Cars 848981.46
NA Vintage Cars 798268.69
NA Motorcycles 524549.19
EMEA Motorcycles 503096.70
EMEA Trucks and Buses 498305.82
EMEA Planes 476122.91
NA Trucks and Buses 449788.40
EMEA Ships 427264.68
NA Planes 353942.96
NA Ships 249997.15
EMEA Trains 138506.18
NA Trains 69253.56 
narrate_descriptive(df_two)

Sales across all Territories is 8.8 M. Outlying Territory by Sales is EMEA (5 M, 56.4 %). Outlying Productlines by Sales are Classic Cars (3.5 M, 39.6 %), Vintage Cars (1.6 M, 18.7 %).

Coverage

Key argument for all narratives is coverage. It is used to narrate the most important things and avoid simple looping through all of the dimension levels.

By default coverage is set to 0.5 and this means that narration will stop as soon as cumulative sum reaches 50 % mark. With increased coverage, additional narrative is returned.

df_three <- sales %>%
  group_by(Productline) %>%
  summarise(Sales = sum(Sales, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(Sales))

df_three %>%
  mutate(Share = round(Sales/sum(Sales)*100, 1),
         Cumulative = cumsum(Share)) %>%
  kable()
Productline Sales Share Cumulative
Classic Cars 3919615.7 39.1 39.1
Vintage Cars 1903150.8 19.0 58.1
Motorcycles 1166388.3 11.6 69.7
Trucks and Buses 1127789.8 11.2 80.9
Planes 975003.6 9.7 90.6
Ships 714437.1 7.1 97.7
Trains 226243.5 2.3 100.0 
narrate_descriptive(df_three)

Sales across all Productlines is 10 M. Outlying Productlines by Sales are Classic Cars (3.9 M, 39.1 %), Vintage Cars (1.9 M, 19 %).

narrate_descriptive(df_three, coverage = 0.7)

Sales across all Productlines is 10 M. Outlying Productlines by Sales are Classic Cars (3.9 M, 39.1 %), Vintage Cars (1.9 M, 19 %), Motorcycles (1.2 M, 11.6 %), Trucks and Buses (1.1 M, 11.2 %).

Changing Templates

Template-based systems are based on calculations of individual variables, and combining them together inside of the template. You can return a list of calculated variables and full narrative realization:

narrate_descriptive(df_three, coverage = 0.7, return_data = TRUE)

$narrative_total Sales across all Productlines is 10 M.

$narrative Sales across all Productlines is 10 M. Outlying Productlines by Sales are Classic Cars (3.9 M, 39.1 %), Vintage Cars (1.9 M, 19 %), Motorcycles (1.2 M, 11.6 %), Trucks and Buses (1.1 M, 11.2 %).

$narrative_outlier_final Outlying Productlines by Sales are Classic Cars (3.9 M, 39.1 %), Vintage Cars (1.9 M, 19 %), Motorcycles (1.2 M, 11.6 %), Trucks and Buses (1.1 M, 11.2 %).

$measure [1] “Sales”

[[5]] [1] “Productline”

$total [1] “10 M”

$outlier_insight [1] “Classic Cars (3.9 M, 39.1 %), Vintage Cars (1.9 M, 19 %), Motorcycles (1.2 M, 11.6 %), Trucks and Buses (1.1 M, 11.2 %)”

Let’s change a template for our narrative function and rework the wording as well as changing ‘is’ to ‘are’ since Sales is plural:

narrate_descriptive(
  df_three,
  narrative_total = "Overall {measure} for all {pluralize(dimension1)} are equal to {total}. ")

Overall Sales for all Productlines are equal to 10 M. Outlying Productlines by Sales are Classic Cars (3.9 M, 39.1 %), Vintage Cars (1.9 M, 19 %).
